answer_html: And we note our answer from computing the nullspace versus the cross product is a multiple of -1 but either one can be used as \(u_3\) for the orthonormal basis of \(\mathbb{R}^3\)
answer_latex:
And we note our answer from computing the nullspace versus the cross
product is a multiple of -1 but either one can be used as $u_3$ for the
orthonormal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
\(u_3\) is orthogonal to the R(A) since it is a part of the orthonormal basis for \(\mathbb{R}^3\)

Recall that \(R(A)^\perp =N(A^T)\)

Since the dim of \(N(A^T)=1\) , the basis of \(N(A^T)\) is \(u_3\)

We can find \(u_3\) either by finding \(N(A^T)\) or using gram-schmidt process or with cross products

We solve it by finding \(N(A^T)\)

\(A^Tu_3=0\)

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0& 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} a\\ b\\ c \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(a=c\)

\(b=-a\)

\(N(A^T)= \{\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\}\)

Normalize the vector

\(u_3= \frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

Alternatively, if you did not recognize that \(u_3 \in N(A^T)\) we can still compute \(u_3\) with cross product

\(u_3=u_1\times u_2= \begin{vmatrix} i & j &k \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt2} &\frac{1}{\sqrt2} &0 \\ -\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} \end{vmatrix}\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix} -1\\ 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\)

And we note our answer from computing the nullspace versus the cross product is a multiple of -1 but either one can be used as \(u_3\) for the orthonormal basis of \(\mathbb{R}^3\)
sols_latex:
$u_3$ is orthogonal to the R(A) since it is a part of the orthonormal
basis for $\mathbb{R}^3$

Recall that $R(A)^\perp =N(A^T)$

Since the dim of $N(A^T)=1$ , the basis of $N(A^T)$ is $u_3$

We can find $u_3$ either by finding $N(A^T)$ or using gram-schmidt
process or with cross products

We solve it by finding $N(A^T)$

$A^Tu_3=0$

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 0 \\
0& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
a\\
b\\
c
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}$

$a=c$

$b=-a$

$N(A^T)= \{\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\}$

Normalize the vector

$u_3= \frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}$

Alternatively, if you did not recognize that $u_3 \in N(A^T)$ we can
still compute $u_3$ with cross product

$u_3=u_1\times u_2= \begin{vmatrix}
i & j &k \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt2} &\frac{1}{\sqrt2} &0 \\
-\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}
\end{vmatrix}$

$=\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}$

And we note our answer from computing the nullspace versus the cross
product is a multiple of -1 but either one can be used as $u_3$ for the
orthonormal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$

<math>u_3</math> is orthogonal to the R(A) since it is a part of the orthonormal basis for <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math>

Recall that <math>R(A)^\perp =N(A^T)</math>

Since the dim of <math>N(A^T)=1</math> , the basis of <math>N(A^T)</math> is <math>u_3</math>

We can find <math>u_3</math> either by finding <math>N(A^T)</math> or using gram-schmidt process or with cross products

We solve it by finding <math>N(A^T)</math>

<math>A^Tu_3=0</math>

<math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 0 \\
0& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
a\\
b\\
c
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}</math>

<math>a=c</math>

<math>b=-a</math>

<math>N(A^T)= \{\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\}</math>

Normalize the vector

<math>u_3= \frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

Alternatively, if you did not recognize that <math>u_3 \in N(A^T)</math> we can still compute <math>u_3</math> with cross product

<math>u_3=u_1\times u_2= \begin{vmatrix}
i & j &k \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt2} &\frac{1}{\sqrt2} &0 \\
-\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\frac{\sqrt2}{2\sqrt3} &\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}
\end{vmatrix}</math>

<math>=\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

And we note our answer from computing the nullspace versus the cross product is a multiple of -1 but either one can be used as <math>u_3</math> for the orthonormal basis of <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math>
statement_html:
A matrix A and a vector b are given by

\(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(\displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}\)

Find an orthonormal basis for \(\mathbb{R}^3: \{ u_1,u_2,u_3\}\) in which \(u_1,u_2\) span the column space R(A) of the matrix A. How does the third basis vector \(u_3\) relate to the fundamental subspaces of A?
statement_latex:
A matrix \emph{A} and a vector \emph{b} are given by

$\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

$\displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}$

Find an orthonormal basis for $\mathbb{R}^3: \{ u_1,u_2,u_3\}$ in which
$u_1,u_2$ span the column space R(A) of the matrix A. How does the third
basis vector $u_3$ relate to the fundamental subspaces of A?
statement_raw:
A matrix ''A'' and a vector ''b'' are given by

<math> \displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math>

<math> \displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}</math>

Find an orthonormal basis for <math>\mathbb{R}^3: \{ u_1,u_2,u_3\}</math> in which <math>u_1,u_2</math> span the column space R(A) of the matrix A. How does the third basis vector <math>u_3</math> relate to the fundamental subspaces of A?
